I'm having similar issues when test code that uses dom4j (which uses 
JAXP to instantiate an XML parser, like Xerces).  When I run under 
junit, it can't find some org.xml classes.  When I run standalone I 
have no problems.

If anyone knows why, I'd love to find out.

--- In junit@y..., Anthony  Pereira <apereira@3...> wrote:
> Hi, 
> 
> I'm not sure whether this is the place to submit what I'm just 
going to
> write about, if not please do point me in the right direction, 
cheers.
> 
> I came across a rather bizzare scenario, today using the
> junit.swingui.TestRunner in a java 1.4beta2 environment. In some of 
my code,
> I reference classes in org.w3c.dom and org.apache.crimson. Now, as 
soon as
> junit came across classes from these packages, it threw class not 
found
> exceptions. Please note that this doesn't happen in the the textui 
nor my
> own testing classes, since they are both in the classpath.
> 
> org.w3c.dom specifically is in the rt.jar
> org.apache.crimson is a separate jar, which is on my classpath
> 
> After a bit of digging around in the source code, specifically in 
the
> TestCaseClassLoader, I found out about the 
junit\runner\exclude.properties
> file. When I added these package names to that file, things seemed 
ok, and
> those exceptions didn't take place.
> 
> What confused me was why it didn't find the classes, even though 
they was on
> my classpath, especially the org.w3c ones which are in the rt.jar 
(with
> 1.4). Furthermore, this was only a problem when using the swingui, 
with the
> textui, it was fine.
> 
> I've got it working now that I put those details in the 
exclude.properties
> file. Is this perhaps a issue with using 1.4?
> 
> Any comments or explainations?
> Thanks
> Anthony
